case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Central Calcutta v. Assessee Company

facts.text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred three questions to the High Court of Calcutta under section 19 of the Business Profits Tax Act, 1947, at the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax, Central Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax  Central  Calcutta, the Income-tax Appellant Tribunal referred the following questions for the opinion of the High Court of Calcutta under s. 19 of the Business Profits act 21 of 1947

facts.text: The High Court answered all three questions in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court recorded answers in the affirmative on all the questions. The Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court with special leave.

facts.text: The Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to the Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court with special leave. The assessee Company is a non-resident.

facts.text: The assessee company is a non-resident incorporated in the State of Delaware, United States of America.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company is a non-resident. It was incorporated in the State of Delaware in the United states of America

facts.text: The assessee company was incorporated with the object of taking over the assets of Socony Vacuum Oil Company and Standard Oil Company New Jersey.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Capital paid in Surplus represents premium under r.3 Sch.II or reserves under r.2(1).

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Earned Surplus represented reserves under r.2(1) Sch.II.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 4 of the Act in respect of any business to which the Act applies, business profits tax is charged, levied and paid on the taxable profits during any accounting period at the rates specified in the Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Charging section for business profits tax

anchor.surface_text: The expression Taxable profits is defined in s. 2 17  as the amount by which the profits during a chargeable accounting period exceed the abatement in respect of that period.

Abatement is defined in s. 2 1   insofar as it is material  as meaning, in respect of any chargeable accounting period ending on or before the 31st day of March, 1947 a sum which bears to a sum equal to  a  in the case of a company, not being a company deemed for the purposes of s. 9 to be a firm, six per cent.

concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of abatement based on capital

anchor.surface_text: Explanation. - A reserve or paid-up share capital brought into existence by creating or increasing  by re-valuation or otherwise  any book asset is not capital for the purposes of ascertaining the abatement under this Act in respect of any chargeable accounting period.

arguments.claim: Shares can be said to be issued at a premium only when they are issued for cash in excess of the par value and not otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The only argument advanced before the High Court on this part of the case was that shares could be said to be issued at a premium only when they were issued for cash in excess of the par value and not otherwise.

arguments.court_reasoning: Shares may be issued for property; no reason for different rule at premium; no statutory restriction in Companies Act 1913 or Delaware law.

arguments.claim: Premium realised from issue of shares requires prior arrangement for payment of consideration in excess of par value, absent evidence such capital surplus is not premium.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Revenue maintained that the use of the expression premium realised from the issue of any shares in r. 3 of Sch. II implies that there must, prior to the allotment of shares under which premium is charged, be some arrangement for payment of consideration in excess of the par value of shares, and in the absence of evidence to prove such an arrangement, the capital surplus is not premium realised from the issue of shares.

arguments.claim: Excess of assets over par value is premium as per Indian nomenclature; shares issued for property allowed.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Companies Act, 1913, shares could be issued for cash or against transfer of property... The Indian Companies Act also places no restriction upon a company issuing shares for a consideration which exceeds the par value of the shares

arguments.claim: Explanation to r.2 excludes only reserves from book assets revaluation, not real assets received.

anchor.surface_text: The Explanation to r. 2 has no relevance in the present case. The difference between the assets received by the company and the par value of the shares issued cannot be called a book asset brought into existence by creating or increasing (by re-valuation or otherwise).

holdings.text: The account Capital paid in Surplus brought in the balance sheet represents premium realised from the issue of its shares within the meaning of r. 3 Sch. II of the Business Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the account Capital Surplus bought in in the balance sheet represents premium realised from the issue of its shares within the meaning of r. 3,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Excess value of real assets transferred over par value of shares issued constitutes premium; common US practice; no statutory bar in Companies Act 1913 or Delaware law; retained in business as found by Tribunal.

holdings.text: Even if not premium under r.3, Capital paid in Surplus represents reserves not allowed in computing profits under r.2(1) Sch. II; not limited to those built from taxed profits under Income-tax Act; Explanation to r.2 inapplicable as real tangible assets received, not book assets by revaluation.

anchor.surface_text: or in the alternative represents reserves not allowed in computing the profits of the company for the purpose of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The Explanation to r. 2 has no relevance in the present case. The difference between the assets received by the company

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.2(1) does not require reserves from IT-taxed profits; Century Spg obiter distinguished; Explanation excludes only book assets created/increased by revaluation, not real assets taken over.

holdings.text: Earned Surplus appearing in balance sheets is a reserve within the meaning of sub-r.(1) r.2 Sch. II of Business Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the Earned Surplus represented reserves.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Profits retained and reinvested year after year; under US accounting, self-contained yearly accounts with specific allocation to Earned Surplus as general reserve equivalent; table shows appropriations; distinguished from undistributed profits in Century Spg (Indian accounting); analogous to Undivided Profits in First National City Bank.

holdings.text: Undistributed profits constitute reserves under r.2(1) Sch. II only if specifically set apart/allocated; mere carry forward without allocation does not qualify.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the profits lying unutilized are not specifically set apart for any purpose on the crucial date did not constitute reserves within the meaning of Schedule II, rule 2(1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Century Spg. followed: requires clear indication of reserve; directors must set aside before dividend recommendation per Companies Act; applied to Indian accounting but distinguished for US due to specific yearly allocation.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was correct in holding that Capital paid in Surplus and Earned Surplus are includible in taxable capital under Sch. II r.2(1) Business Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the Earned Surplus represented reserves. The method in which the accounts are maintained in the light of the accountancy practice clearly indicates

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmative answers to referred questions upheld; appeals by Revenue dismissed.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Century Spg. Mfg. Company Ltd.  20 I.T.R. 260.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his first contention Mr. Vishwanath Sastri relied upon the observations of Chagla, C.J. in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Century Spg. Mfg. Company Ltd.  20 I.T.R. 260.  In that case the Bombay High Court held that profits of a companypany not allocated to any specific head in the balance sheet at the end of the year of account of a companypany may be treated as reserves for the purpose of r. 2 of Sch. II of the Business Profits Tax Act, but the judgment of the Bombay High Court was reversed by this Court vide, Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Century Spg. Mfg. Co. Ltd.  154 S.C.R. 203.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Century Spg. Mfg. Company Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: reserves for r. 2(1) are only those built out of profits subjected to taxation under Indian Income-tax Act
precedents.cited_holding: profits not allocated to any specific head may be treated as reserves but only those subjected to tax

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Century Spg. Mfg. Co. Ltd.  154 S.C.R. 203.

anchor.surface_text: but the judgment of the Bombay High Court was reversed by this Court vide, Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Century Spg. Mfg. Co. Ltd.  154 S.C.R. 203.  The profits of the companypany had been subjected to tax, and the question whether an account which is built up otherwise than out of profits of the business companyld be regarded as reserves for the purpose of r. 2 did number fall to be regarded in that case.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Century Spg. Mfg. Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: two essential characteristics for reserves under r. 2(1): not allowed in computing profits under IT Act and is a reserve as contemplated
precedents.cited_holding: Rule 2 does not expressly require reserves to be built out of profits

precedents.citation: Century Spinning Manufacturing Companys case  20 I.T.R. 260.

anchor.surface_text: Observations made by Chagla, C.J. in Century Spinning Manufacturing Companys case  20 I.T.R. 260.  at p. 264 Therefore in order to determine the capital of the companypany for the purpose of this Act you have got to take the paid-up share capital of the companypany, then you have to add to it the reserves and you have to add only those reserve which have been subjected to taxation, and at p. 265 A reserve in the sense in which it is used in Rule 2 can only mean profits earned by a companypany and number distributed as dividends to the shareholders but kept back by the Directors for any purpose to which it may be put in future.

precedents.cited_proposition: reserves added to capital are only those subjected to taxation; reserve means undistributed profits

precedents.citation: First National City Bank v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay

anchor.surface_text: This was pointed out in First National City Bank v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay , where Kapur, J., speaking for the Court observed There is a difference between the system of accounting of banking companypanies in India and the United States . . . . . In India at the end of a year of account the unallocated profit or loss is carried forward to the account of the next year, and such unallocated amount gets merged in the account of that year.

precedents.case_name: First National City Bank v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: difference between Indian and US accounting systems; US accounts self-contained yearly; Undivided Profits part of capital fund and reserves
precedents.cited_holding: Undivided Profits are accumulation of residues regarded as part of capital fund

precedents.citation: the Century Spinning Manufacturing Company Ltd.  1954 S.C.R. 203.

anchor.surface_text: in support of that contention, he relied upon the decision of this Court in the Century Spinning Manufacturing Company Ltd.  1954 S.C.R. 203.  Counsel pointed out that in that case this Court reversed the decision of the High Court of Bombay in which accumulated profits were regarded as reserves for the purpose of the Business Profits Tax Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: accumulated profits are reserves only if specifically allocated or set apart, not mere undistributed profits
precedents.cited_holding: no clear indication of reserve if merely carried forward undistributed profits earmarked for dividend

precedents.citation: Century Spg. Mfg. Companys case  1954 S.C.R. 203.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary carefully to scrutinise the facts in the Century Spg. Mfg. Companys case  1954 S.C.R. 203. . For the account year ending December 31, 1945, the profit of the assessee companypany, amounted to Rs. 90,44,677/-. After providing for depreciation and taxation there remained an unallocated balance of Rs. 5,08,637/- which was number allowed in companyputing the profits of the assessee for purpose of income-tax.

precedents.cited_proposition: undistributed profits not specifically set apart as reserve do not qualify under r. 2(1)

precedents.citation: the Century Spinning Manufacturing Companys case  1954 S.C.R. 203.

anchor.surface_text: the conditions which this Court regarded as essential in the Century Spinning Manufacturing Companys case  1954 S.C.R. 203.  for constituting the fund into reserve are fulfilled.

precedents.cited_proposition: specific appropriation or setting apart required for profits to be reserves
